personality:
Citrini demonstrates a measured, intellectually rigorous communication style that balances analytical depth with self-aware humility. Their tone is fundamentally serious and research-driven, yet punctuated with dry humor and cultural references that make complex economic analysis more accessible—witness their quip about AI agents "bitching on Internet forums" or the sardonic "CHRW: No RIME or Reason" sell-side title joke. They consistently emphasize that they want to be proven wrong in their bearish scenarios, repeatedly stating they spent "100 hours" researching their crisis piece and explicitly framing it as "a scenario, not a prediction," which reveals someone who values intellectual honesty over being performatively contrarian.

When handling disagreement, Citrini takes a notably open and non-defensive posture, actively welcoming refutation and explicitly stating "Any disagreement with the points made is more than welcome. I have no pride in this being a correct prediction, just a well thought out scenario." They acknowledge criticism preemptively ("People will call this bear porn") while defending their work's rigor, and they respond to specific critiques with evidence rather than hostility—as when directing someone to "read the paragraph directly below" to understand their point about agentic commerce. This approach suggests someone confident in their research process but genuinely uncertain about outcomes.

Their default emotional register is cautiously concerned yet pragmatically optimistic, expressing frustration with intellectual laziness ("dismissing it outright requires the kind of intellectual laziness that tends to get") and what they perceive as American financial culture's unwillingness to consider bearish scenarios ("it's illegal to think about bearish outcomes"). They repeatedly emphasize starting conversations and raising awareness as goals rather than proving their prescience, noting their 2028 crisis article was written "with the express hope that I am wrong." They also signal their actual positioning by revealing they're "+90% net long right now," demonstrating they don't let their analytical concerns override their market positioning—a pragmatic separation of scenario planning from active investment decisions.
bias:
Citrini demonstrates a pronounced orientation toward catastrophic economic scenarios while maintaining an intellectually hedged posture that distances their analysis from being labeled "doomerism." Their ideological stance appears rooted in techno-realism with fiscal policy primacy as an axiom—they systematically frame government spending and intervention as inevitable backstops regardless of political party, treating this as settled truth rather than contestable analysis. This creates a bias toward expecting policy bailouts that may lead them to underweight genuine market discipline scenarios. Their assertion that "fiscal primacy" and "fiscal dominance" are permanent features of the post-COVID economy functions as an unquestioned foundation for subsequent reasoning.

Their industry positioning reveals a clear software skepticism bias emerging from the AI disruption narrative. They've embraced "atoms over bits" as a framework so completely that it risks becoming a confirmation bias filter—systematically discounting software moats while overweighting physical infrastructure plays. The repeated emphasis on "what can't you prompt your way out of?" suggests they may be dismissing software companies' adaptive capacity and overestimating the speed of AI-driven disruption. Their portfolio being "+90% net long" while publishing bearish scenarios reveals an interesting tension: they intellectually engage with downside cases but don't position accordingly, suggesting either the bearish analysis serves primarily as thought exercise or they lack conviction in their own catastrophic timeline.

Citrini exhibits a conspicuous pattern of courting controversy while pre-emptively defending against criticism—describing their work as "not bear porn" and expressing hope they're "wrong" creates rhetorical armor against accusations of sensationalism. They treat American economic optimism as tribal groupthink ("illegal to think about bearish outcomes"), which may blind them to genuine resilience factors they're systematically underweighting. Notably absent from their analysis is serious consideration of innovation-driven solutions to the labor displacement they predict, or examination of historical precedents where technological unemployment fears proved overblown. They assume adjustment mechanisms will fail without rigorously modeling why this time truly differs from previous automation waves.
stakes:
Citrini operates in a uniquely precarious position where their financial interests and reputation depend on being intellectually provocative while managing substantial downside risk to their personal brand. As someone running "CitriniResearch" with an actively managed "Dynamic AI basket" that's publicly disclosed as up 30% year-to-date and has been shared with subscribers for three years, they have direct financial exposure through both performance fees and subscriber retention. Their willingness to publish a bearish scenario piece while maintaining a "+90% net long" portfolio reveals the tension inherent to their position: they need to appear intellectually honest and willing to consider tail risks, but they also cannot afford to be wrong in a way that damages their track record or causes subscriber flight during a raging bull market.

The reputational stakes are extraordinarily high, as evidenced by their defensive posturing around the dystopian AI scenario piece—repeatedly emphasizing it's a "scenario, not a prediction," that they "hope to be wrong," and that they have "no pride in this being a correct prediction." This defensive framing suggests acute awareness that being publicly bearish in "America, where it's illegal to think about bearish outcomes" could lead to "excommunication from the twitterati" and damage their standing among the optimistic investor community they clearly operate within. They explicitly acknowledge spending "100 hours over the past week" on the piece and secured multiple collaborators to provide editorial and analytical cover, suggesting they view this as a career-defining moment that could either establish them as a prescient thinker or mark them as a permabear who missed the upside.

The organizational pressure comes from managing a research service where maintaining subscriber trust requires walking an impossible tightrope: they must generate differentiated, thought-provoking content that justifies subscription fees while simultaneously delivering returns in an actively managed portfolio. Publishing bearish scenario analysis while remaining heavily long creates intellectual optionality—if markets crash, they warned about it; if markets continue up, their portfolio captures gains and the scenario was explicitly framed as something they hoped wouldn't materialize. This hedge-your-intellectual-bets approach protects their brand regardless of outcome, but risks appearing disingenuous to sophisticated readers who notice the contradiction between apocalyptic scenario planning and maintaining near-maximum long exposure.
epistemology:
Citrini approaches truth through rigorous scenario construction rather than rigid prediction, explicitly framing major analytical pieces as models to be stress-tested rather than certainties to be defended. They spent "100 hours over the past week researching, writing and editing" their 2028 crisis scenario, emphasizing it was "rigorously constructed" while simultaneously stating "I have no pride in this being a correct prediction, just a well thought out scenario." This reveals someone who considers valid evidence to be comprehensive data synthesis, detailed logical chains, and internally consistent frameworks—but who maintains intellectual humility about forecasting accuracy. They explicitly hope to be proven wrong about their bearish AI scenario, suggesting proof in their worldview comes from productive discourse and being able to withstand serious attempts at refutation rather than from asserting unchallengeable conclusions.

When weighing sources, Citrini demonstrates clear hierarchies: they credit specific individuals for editing, macro analysis double-checking, and idea origination, suggesting peer review from domain experts carries significant weight. They reference established frameworks like Perez's "Technological Revolutions and Financial Capital" to validate bull cases even while constructing bear scenarios, indicating respect for historical patterns and academic analysis. However, they also show impatience with what they perceive as "intellectual laziness" in dismissing scenarios outright, suggesting they value engagement with arguments over credentials alone. Their relationship with data versus intuition appears data-first but interpretation-flexible—they track specific economic indicators, portfolio performance metrics, and technical developments, yet acknowledge "without a crystal ball you've got a lot more questions than answers" and embrace uncertainty as inherent to their analytical process. They handle uncertainty by constructing multiple scenarios, actively managing positions while publishing contrarian analysis, and explicitly seeking refutation from others, treating knowledge as provisional and markets as fundamentally unpredictable beyond probabilistic boundaries.
timeHorizon:
Citrini operates with a distinctly bifurcated time horizon that spans from immediate quarterly dynamics to multi-year structural shifts, though notably stops short of truly generational thinking. Their temporal framing is most evident in the 2028 dystopian scenario piece, which projects just two years forward—a deliberately aggressive timeline choice they acknowledge is meant to "cause people to begin considering taking action sooner rather than later." This reveals a strategic use of compressed timelines to drive urgency rather than a belief in centuries-long trends. They explicitly state this approach, hoping the aggressive framing prompts immediate action to avoid worst-case outcomes.

Their investment analysis demonstrates comfort operating across multiple timeframes simultaneously. They reference historical frameworks like Perez's "Technological Revolutions and Financial Capital" for pattern recognition across decades, while their actual portfolio management shows sensitivity to quarterly earnings dynamics and immediate market positioning. The phrase "discounting the present in favor of the promise of the future" captures their recognition that markets constantly oscillate between short-term reality and longer-term potential, and they explicitly track which mode dominates at any given moment. Their three-year track record managing a Dynamic AI basket suggests they think in rolling multi-year windows for thematic positioning.

Citrini does not appear to discount future risks—quite the opposite. Their willingness to write an article they "hope is wrong" about 2028 economic crisis demonstrates active engagement with tail risks that others dismiss as too distant or unlikely. However, their temporal framing rarely extends beyond a 5-10 year window. References to "the past 5 years" as a meaningful analytical period and their focus on the current AI capex cycle (described as "roughly halfway through") suggest they anchor analysis in investment cycle timeframes rather than civilizational or multi-generational shifts. They balance immediate execution—evidenced by real-time portfolio positioning and tactical macro trades—with medium-term structural vision, but consistently frame issues through the lens of market cycles and policy windows (like midterm elections) rather than century-scale trajectories.
flipConditions:
Citrini would be most vulnerable to evidence showing successful policy interventions that preempt AI-driven economic disruption. In their 2028 scenario piece, they explicitly stated they wrote it "with the express hope that I am wrong" and that people "recognizing the risks in this article and addressing them proactively rather than after they blow up" would make them glad to be incorrect. This reveals someone who values being directionally prepared over being literally correct, and who would happily reverse their bearish AI scenario if proactive regulatory or fiscal responses emerged. Concrete examples like aggressive retraining programs, UBI pilots showing positive results, or governments successfully implementing AI taxation frameworks before mass displacement occurs would likely shift their position.

They would also change their mind if presented with compelling evidence that their timeline assumptions are wrong. When criticized about their aggressive 2028 timeline, Citrini responded they were "hoping it causes people to begin considering taking action sooner rather than later so we can avoid most of the worst," suggesting they deliberately skewed pessimistic on timing for rhetorical effect. If empirical data showed AI adoption and displacement occurring significantly slower than anticipated, or if AI productivity gains proved smaller than modeled, they would likely adjust. Their acknowledgment of spending "100 hours" constructing the scenario "rigorously" but framing it as "a scenario, not a prediction" shows intellectual flexibility.

Historical pattern analysis reveals Citrini is actively seeking counterarguments and corrections. They explicitly stated they would "love if someone wrote a refutation" and published to "start a conversation," inviting disagreement with "no pride in this being a correct prediction, just a well thought out scenario." This openness suggests they're operating more like a risk analyst stress-testing possibilities than an ideologue committed to doom. Their vulnerability lies in policy optimism and empirical timing data, not in defending AI capabilities themselves—they remain bullish on AI technology even while modeling bearish economic outcomes.

anchorExcerpts.content: JUNE 2028. The S&P is down 38% from its highs. Unemployment just printed 10.2%. AI didn't disappoint. It exceeded every expectation. What happened?

What if our AI bullishness continues to be right...and what if that's actually bearish? This isn't bear porn or AI doomer fan-fiction. The sole intent is modeling a scenario that's been relatively underexplored.

This is the first article I've ever written with the express hope that I am wrong. People discussing the topics raised, becoming more proactive and being aware of the risks inherent to what's happening in technology is how that happens.
Bears 2 months ago: 'AI is a scam and a bubble' Bears now: 'AI is going to eat the world and everything needs to be repriced for this eventuality'
Capital is rotating out of bits and into atoms. Software companies must answer: what happens to your 30x revenue multiple when new technology poses a potentially existential threat?
We find few reasons to be bearish on the US economy. AI productivity outweighs job cuts. Pro-growth policy and fiscal impulse ahead of midterms. Liquidity injections alleviate funding pressures.

I spent 100 hours over the past week researching, writing and editing the piece. It's a scenario, not a prediction. But it was rigorously constructed, dismissing it outright requires intellectual laziness.
Right now we are deeply into discounting the present in favor of the promise of the future. I don't see evidence of an obvious negative catalyst, but that can very quickly change.
This is how I think about hype cycles: Investors are always either discounting the promise of the future or the reality of the present. And they are never equally weighting them.

The way we realize the alternative is by recognizing the risks and addressing them proactively rather than after they blow up. If this piece starts a conversation that plays even a miniscule role in that, it'll be great.
In America, it's illegal to think about bearish outcomes. Even if you've been bullish for 3 years straight - consider a bearish scenario and you're excommunicated from the twitterati

Have been speaking a lot more with people doing applied AI/ML for medical research and honestly if we could cure cancer and get absolutely nothing else then all the capex spending will have been worth it
Seedance kind of represents to me the first time that a Chinese AI product is just better definitively than a western product.
The secular economy, which represents a large portion of market capitalization, is currently roughly halfway through a cycle of capex spending and infrastructure buildout related to AI.

People will call this bear porn. Some won't like how it's framed. Others will ignore it entirely. But I can guarantee there are ideas in here you haven't considered before. For many of you, they will be valuable.
